newsitem.title: UK: Britain approves Lloyd's rescue package.
newsitem.headline: Britain approves Lloyd's rescue package.

text.p: The British government said on Wednesday it had approved the Lloyd's of London insurance market's 3.2 billion pound recovery plan.
The plan has been overwhelmingly accepted by Lloyd's investors, known as Names.
"Lloyd's is now able to to complete its reconstruction and renewal programme," the Department of Trade and Industry said.
Under the recovery proposals, Lloyd's would reinsure billions of pounds in liabilities into a new company, Equitas.

"The fulfilment of Lloyd's reconstruction plan will enhance the security, capacity and competitiveness not only of the British insurance and reinsurance industry, but also of wider capital markets in the UK," said Anthony Nelson, Minister of State for Trade and Industry, in a statement.

He said he would require Lloyd's to provide up to an extra 100 million pounds ($156.1 million), to mitigate the effects on Equitas' reserves of lower than projected interest rates or a shortfall in the contributions due from agents or brokers, if so requested by Equitas in January 2002. ($1=.6406 Pound)
